body.head.byline: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

block.p: As summer fast approaches, the temperature in the deal world is rising as well. On Thursday, Biomet, a maker of artificial joints, accepted a sweetened $11.4 billion offer from a group of private equity firms. The new proposal arrived as shareholders indicated that they would reject the consortium's $10.9 billion previous offer as too low.

On Monday, Avaya, one of the world's biggest makers of corporate phone equipment, agreed to an $8.2 billion deal with Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group. The two private equity firms, which bested Nortel Networks in the bidding, will pay $17.50 a share.

On Monday, Avaya, one of the world's biggest makers of corporate phone equipment, agreed to an $8.2 billion deal with Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group. The two private equity firms, which bested Nortel Networks in the bidding, will pay $17.50 a share.

That same day, Palm said that it would sell a 25 percent stake in itself to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm that counts Bono among its co-founders, for $325 million. The sale comes as the company's cellphones lose market share to rival devices running the BlackBerry or Windows Mobile systems.
And it was reported Monday that Cadence Design Systems, which makes the software that designs computer chips, has held talks with at least two private equity firms about going private.

Though private equity has found resounding success in acquiring companies over the last two years, fears of rising interest rates may bring the buyout boom to a halt, as the debt fueling the acquisition spree becomes too expensive.
